comments.author: doctordns
comments.body:
First off - VS Code replaces ISE. The $PSISE object is different, but anything you can do in ISE you can do with VS Code.

You can target VS Code at Windows PowerShell if you choose to and change versions of PowerShell to use. It's quite easy.

```powershell
# load the assemblies 
[void] [System.Reflection.Assembly]::LoadWithPartialName("System.Drawing")  
[void] [System.Reflection.Assembly]::LoadWithPartialName("System.Windows.Forms") 
[void] [System.Windows.Forms.Application]::EnableVisualStyles() 
# Put up a message block:
[System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox]::Show('Would  you like to play a game?','Game input','YesNoCancel','Error')
```

Works great.

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
Visual Studio is not required, I'm not even sure it's recommended.

Visual Studio Code is a different (completely free) product entirely, and the PowerShell extension for it is what's maintained directly by the PS team.

But yes, Windows PowerShell / the ISE are frozen. The ISE contains many components not owned by the PS team and from what I recall being said previously there were a multitude of legal issues with open sourcing it, so it had to be dropped as the team is focusing on open sourcing their core products. Both pwsh and the PowerShell extension for VS Code are open source.
